By T P. S.
The Johns Hopkins University
has the unique distinction of providing the Chinese Republic with
three consecutive constitutional advisors. One of these, Dr. W. Willoughby, who has just returned to
the University, was the principal
advisor to the Chinese delegation
at the Washington Conference for
Limitation of Armaments.
On March 13, 1913, Dr. Frank
Johnson Goodnow, now President
0; the Johns Hopkins University,
Was appointed Constitutional Advisor to the Chinese Government at
Pekin. His task in China was
mostly concerned with framing a
Permanent constitution. Problems
a, to
Should be instituted, whether it
should be unitary or federal in
form; or what powers should be
Vested in the central government,
and which ones should be left to
the provinces, were the questions
to be olved by the young Chinese
epublic. Dr. Goodnow was called
Upon to give advice on these and
similar questions.
In the middle of the year 1914,
Professor Goodnow resigned his
Position as Constitutional Advisor
to the first republic in the Far East
and entered upon his duties as Presluent of the Johns Hopkins University, October 1, 1914.
The successor to the Hopkins
President as Constitutional Advisor to the Chinese Government was
Dr. William Franklin Willoughby,
graduate of the Johns Hopkins
University in 1888. Professor Willoughby has rendered valuable assistance to the United States Government since 1890, when he was an
:pert in the United States Department of Labor. Subsequently, he
represented this country several
times at international congresses
and made labor investigations for
it in Europe.
From 1901 to 1907, Professor
Wiloughby was treasurer of Porto
Rico, which was then in a formattve period of civil government. He
Was later Secretary of Porto Rico,
and President of the Executive
Council of the Legislative Assembly of that state from 1907 to 1909.
Dr. Willoughby served as Constitutional Advisor to the Chinese
Government from the middle of
1914 to the middle of 1916. His
duties were similar to those of his
Predecessor. In 1916 he resigned
his position of Advisor
to the Chinese Republic.
When Dr. Willoughby was in
China, the twenty-one demands of
Japan were sent to the Chinese
Government at Pekin, Referring
to these demands, Dr. W. F. Willoughby stated in an interview with
the writer on Wednesday, January
1922: "The twenty-one demands of Japan was a case of international brigandry. Japan's amwere to dominate China
lie Japanese realized that as the
e'l(ling powers of the world were
at: war, the opportunity was ripe
to force China, without preliminary
notice, to submit to the desires of
Japanese imperialism. They then
Presented the infamous demands.
China was unwilling to submit, but

the issuance of an ultimatum and
the threat of war compelled the
weak Chinese Government to surrender to the designs of Japan. In
fact, Japanese troops had already
begun to move before China had
yielded. The demands of Japan
were not intended as a means of
settling outstanding issues. It was
a pure case of international brigandry."
After his resignation as Constitutional Advisor, Dr. Willoughb
returned to the United States and
became the Director of the Institute of Government Research. He
'is often asked to appear before
Congressional committees and render his advice on administrative
matters. (It was largely due to thc
efforts of Professor W. F. Willoughby that the budgetary system
was adopted by the United States.)

ised by the Homewood Plavshop,
the new dramatic society, on their
next shop night for members and
their friends in the Barn, Thursday evening, February 16. "Suppressed Desires," the well-known
comedy by Susan Glaspell and
George Cram Cook, will be the
principal part of the program, with
a cast composed of Miss Clementine Walter, Mrs. James Nathan
and Douglas Coulter.
Although all three members of
the cast have long been prominent
in university and local amateur
theatre affairs, their appearance in
the Playshop production will introduce them in a new field, so far as
Hopkins dramatics are concerned.
Miss Walter, of course, has already won recognition for her successful work as coach of the Hopkins Dramatic Club for four years.
To her, more than to any one else,
has been ascribed a large measure
of the club's triumphant career.
Miss Walter is directing the production of "Suppressed Desires,"
as well as taking one of the three
lea ding- roles.
"Doug" Coulter, too, is well
known to Hopkins people, having
served as director of the music and
glee clubs, as well as winning fame
for his work in the "Hawaiian
Trio." This will mark Mr. Coulter's debut in a Hopkins dramatic
production. He is a student in the
graduate department this year.
Mrs. Nathan, formerly student
at the university, is one of the leading local amateur players, and has
gained prominence through her
work as organizer of the Vagabond
Players and the Children's Theatre
at the Little Lyric.
The Playshoppers report that
plans for their organization are
making excellent headway and
everything points to an entertainment of unusual merit when they
make their public debut at the Vagabond Theatre on March 24 and 25.
Students and faculty members
from nearly all departments, including the undergraduate school,
have enrolled as members. "Shop"
nights are being held every three
weeks in the Barn.

SENIOR CLASS MEETS

Chairman Bill Totterdale in a
report for the Senior Dance Committee, stated that the Senior Prom
would be held in the next few
weeks. The price for admission
will be five dollars; all classes are
invited to attend.
The question of the dedication of
this year's Hullabaloo was discussed and nominations were called
for. Dr. Mitchell and Dr. Whitehead were nominated and will be
voted on next week.

ADVISERS TO CHINA
Continued from page 1, col. 1

Chinese Government. This was his
twin brother, Dr. Westel Woodbury Willoughby, who also graduated from the undergraduate department of the Johns Hopkins
University in 1888, and received his
degree of Doctor of Philosophy in
1891. All of the three Constitutional Advisors are teachers in the
department of Political Science at
the Johns Hopkins University. Dr.
W. W. Willoughby, the last Advisor, occupies the chair of Professor of Political Science.
The new Constitutional Advisor
served in China from 1916 to 1917.
His work was of the same nature
as that of Dr. Goodnow and his
brother. He has also been the leading Advisor to the Chinese delegation at the Washington Conference for the Limitation of Armaments. While serving in this capacity, it can be strongly contended that he played a most important
part in the formulation of the Ten
Points of China, which were presented before the Conference.
One benefit gained by the Chinese through the occupation of
Shantung by Japan, Dr. W. F. Willoughby states, was the awakening
in the people of China of a national
consciousness. As to the fear in
some circles that China is included
in the "Yellow Peril," Dr. Wil

loughby discredits that. "China,"
he says, "is more friendly to the
United States than to any other
nation. China would not fight the
United States for Japan."
"There are two governments in
China today, the recognized government of the North, and the unrecognized one of the South. The
lz tter was formed under Sun Yat
Sen when the President of Pekin
dissolved the legislature and ruled
by order only.
"The solution of the Chinese
problem lies in the principle of
'Self Determination.' The Chinese
should be allowed to solve their
own difficulties. A treaty embodying a complete 'hands off' policy
should be arranged between all nations interested in China. Only
then will China gradually become
free and independent."

The college man has always been the object of blame where social
revolution in youthful circles is concerned. He has always been blamed

V

for foolish male fads and fashions, but now the sages have acquired
the chimerical idea that the "rah-rah boy" is to blame for the origin
of "petting parties," "bobbed-haired, rolled-stockinged girls," and the
"general moral degeneracy of jazz."
Magazines and papers all over the country have discussed the

The big or little
company—which?

matter. Several colleges admit the criminal tendencies of their pleas-

HEN the talk turns to where should a
Wfellow
start work, a question arises on
men naturally take sides.

ure-loving students; others deny it. Finally, one of our local beacons
of enlightenment comes to the fore with a full page discussion of the
approbious behavior of John J. Jazz, asking at the conclusion, "Is
jazz a menace, a vehicle for sensuality? Or is it youth's revolt against
restraint?

Does the mania for gambling and underdressing signify

degeneracy?"
Jazz is not a menace! It is the modern expression of joy, and the
fact that the two sexes are drawn together in its execution is incidental and not significant. In the war camps, away from the influence
of women, jazz served to raise the spirits of the down-hearted. Man
has always, and quite naturally, sought the company of woman in pleasure. She is an accessory, not the cause of jazz dancing.
Modern (lancing is imprescriptible.

It needs no repression and

will stand for none. There is, of course, the "ball-room bandit," even
as there are extremists at all functions, who require censure. "Petting
parties" and "hip-pocket heroes" are unknown quantities to no college
man, but every such enthusiast exercises his judgment in the presence
of the opposite sex. It is generally the girl who sets the pace; the overindulging youth merely "gets away with" as much as he can.

Chivalry

and respect are not dead! Every girl gets the respect that she demands.
Youth will be served! Is it not better that he give vent to his ef fervescent spirits at well-chaperoned "jazz parties," than to take himself
to unsupervised rendezvous of debauchery?
On with the dance!
MR. PALMER'S ADDRESS
The goal for the Spring Season Ticket Campaign set by Mr. Palmer in his address at last Thursday's Assembly is a high one, but its
attainment is by no means impossible. Success, however, will require
work and hard work, not only on the part of a few, but on the part
of every student at the University.
The ticket to be sold offers many advantages to the buyer and is
of itself a good selling proposition. If the student is imbued with one:tenth of Mr. Palmer:s enthusiasm, he will find no difficulty in selling his
quota. Let us remember that we are all interested in anything for the
welfare .of Hopkins, and adopt as pur motto: "All for each, and each
for all."

Published in
the interest of Electrical Development by
an Institution that will
be helped by whatever helps the
Industry.

which college
"You'll be buried in the big company," say
some. "Everything is red tape and departments working against each other."
"Your little company never gets you anywhere," others assert. "The bigger the
company the bigger your opportunity."
And that seems true—but in a different
sense. Not physical size but bigness of purpose
should be our standard for judging an industrial organization just as it is for judging a man.
Where will you find this company with
a vision?
Whether its plant .covers a hundred acres
or is only a dingy shop up three flights is on
the face of it no indication of what you want
to know—is such and such a company more
concerned with developing men and ideas than
boosting profits at the expense of service?
You must look deeper. What is the organization's standing in the industry What do
its customers say? What do its competitors say?
There are industries and there are companies
which offer you every opportunity to grow.
Spiritually they are as big and broad as the
earnest man hopes to build himself. If you
are that kind of man you will be satisfied with
a company of no lower standards.
Conversely, if you are working for such a
big-souled company, the very fact will argue
that you yourself are a man worth while. For
in business as in social life a man is known by
the company he picks.
The electrical industry needs men who can
see far and think straight.

ideal the hope that it may measure up
to the aspirations of those who work
in it.

By T P. S.
The Johns Hopkins University
has the unique distinction of providing the Chinese Republic with
three consecutive constitutional advisors. One of these, Dr. W. Willoughby, who has just returned to
the University, was the principal
advisor to the Chinese delegation
at the Washington Conference for
Limitation of Armaments.
On March 13, 1913, Dr. Frank
Johnson Goodnow, now President
0; the Johns Hopkins University,
Was appointed Constitutional Advisor to the Chinese Government at
Pekin. His task in China was
mostly concerned with framing a
Permanent constitution. Problems
a, to
Should be instituted, whether it
should be unitary or federal in
form; or what powers should be
Vested in the central government,
and which ones should be left to
the provinces, were the questions
to be olved by the young Chinese
epublic. Dr. Goodnow was called
Upon to give advice on these and
similar questions.
In the middle of the year 1914,
Professor Goodnow resigned his
Position as Constitutional Advisor
to the first republic in the Far East
and entered upon his duties as Presluent of the Johns Hopkins University, October 1, 1914.
The successor to the Hopkins
President as Constitutional Advisor to the Chinese Government was
Dr. William Franklin Willoughby,
graduate of the Johns Hopkins
University in 1888. Professor Willoughby has rendered valuable assistance to the United States Government since 1890, when he was an
:pert in the United States Department of Labor. Subsequently, he
represented this country several
times at international congresses
and made labor investigations for
it in Europe.
From 1901 to 1907, Professor
Wiloughby was treasurer of Porto
Rico, which was then in a formattve period of civil government. He
Was later Secretary of Porto Rico,
and President of the Executive
Council of the Legislative Assembly of that state from 1907 to 1909.
Dr. Willoughby served as Constitutional Advisor to the Chinese
Government from the middle of
1914 to the middle of 1916. His
duties were similar to those of his
Predecessor. In 1916 he resigned
his position of Advisor
to the Chinese Republic.
When Dr. Willoughby was in
China, the twenty-one demands of
Japan were sent to the Chinese
Government at Pekin, Referring
to these demands, Dr. W. F. Willoughby stated in an interview with
the writer on Wednesday, January
1922: "The twenty-one demands of Japan was a case of international brigandry. Japan's amwere to dominate China
lie Japanese realized that as the
e'l(ling powers of the world were
at: war, the opportunity was ripe
to force China, without preliminary
notice, to submit to the desires of
Japanese imperialism. They then
Presented the infamous demands.
China was unwilling to submit, but

were not intended as a means of

matters. (It was largely due to thc

was adopted by the United States.)

ised by the Homewood Plavshop,

Although all three members of

Miss Walter, of course, has already won recognition for her successful work as coach of the Hopkins Dramatic Club for four years.

Mrs. Nathan, formerly student
at the university, is one of the leading local amateur players, and has
gained prominence through her
work as organizer of the Vagabond
Players and the Children's Theatre
at the Little Lyric.
The Playshoppers report that
plans for their organization are
making excellent headway and
everything points to an entertainment of unusual merit when they
make their public debut at the Vagabond Theatre on March 24 and 25.

from nearly all departments, including the undergraduate school,
have enrolled as members. "Shop"
nights are being held every three
weeks in the Barn.

W. W. Willoughby, the last Advisor, occupies the chair of Professor of Political Science.
The new Constitutional Advisor
served in China from 1916 to 1917.
His work was of the same nature
as that of Dr. Goodnow and his
brother. He has also been the leading Advisor to the Chinese delegation at the Washington Conference for the Limitation of Armaments. While serving in this capacity, it can be strongly contended that he played a most important
part in the formulation of the Ten
Points of China, which were presented before the Conference.
One benefit gained by the Chinese through the occupation of
Shantung by Japan, Dr. W. F. Willoughby states, was the awakening
in the people of China of a national
consciousness. As to the fear in
some circles that China is included
in the "Yellow Peril," Dr. Wil

loughby discredits that. "China,"
he says, "is more friendly to the
United States than to any other
nation. China would not fight the
United States for Japan."
"There are two governments in
China today, the recognized government of the North, and the unrecognized one of the South. The
lz tter was formed under Sun Yat
Sen when the President of Pekin
dissolved the legislature and ruled
by order only.
"The solution of the Chinese
problem lies in the principle of
'Self Determination.' The Chinese
should be allowed to solve their
own difficulties. A treaty embodying a complete 'hands off' policy
should be arranged between all nations interested in China. Only
then will China gradually become
free and independent."

The college man has always been the object of blame where social
revolution in youthful circles is concerned. He has always been blamed

V

for foolish male fads and fashions, but now the sages have acquired
the chimerical idea that the "rah-rah boy" is to blame for the origin
of "petting parties," "bobbed-haired, rolled-stockinged girls," and the
"general moral degeneracy of jazz."
Magazines and papers all over the country have discussed the

The big or little
company—which?

matter. Several colleges admit the criminal tendencies of their pleas-

HEN the talk turns to where should a
Wfellow
start work, a question arises on
men naturally take sides.

ure-loving students; others deny it. Finally, one of our local beacons
of enlightenment comes to the fore with a full page discussion of the
approbious behavior of John J. Jazz, asking at the conclusion, "Is
jazz a menace, a vehicle for sensuality? Or is it youth's revolt against
restraint?

Does the mania for gambling and underdressing signify

degeneracy?"
Jazz is not a menace! It is the modern expression of joy, and the
fact that the two sexes are drawn together in its execution is incidental and not significant. In the war camps, away from the influence
of women, jazz served to raise the spirits of the down-hearted. Man
has always, and quite naturally, sought the company of woman in pleasure. She is an accessory, not the cause of jazz dancing.
Modern (lancing is imprescriptible.

It needs no repression and

will stand for none. There is, of course, the "ball-room bandit," even
as there are extremists at all functions, who require censure. "Petting
parties" and "hip-pocket heroes" are unknown quantities to no college
man, but every such enthusiast exercises his judgment in the presence
of the opposite sex. It is generally the girl who sets the pace; the overindulging youth merely "gets away with" as much as he can.

Chivalry

and respect are not dead! Every girl gets the respect that she demands.
Youth will be served! Is it not better that he give vent to his ef fervescent spirits at well-chaperoned "jazz parties," than to take himself
to unsupervised rendezvous of debauchery?
On with the dance!
MR. PALMER'S ADDRESS
The goal for the Spring Season Ticket Campaign set by Mr. Palmer in his address at last Thursday's Assembly is a high one, but its
attainment is by no means impossible. Success, however, will require
work and hard work, not only on the part of a few, but on the part
of every student at the University.
The ticket to be sold offers many advantages to the buyer and is
of itself a good selling proposition. If the student is imbued with one:tenth of Mr. Palmer:s enthusiasm, he will find no difficulty in selling his
quota. Let us remember that we are all interested in anything for the
welfare .of Hopkins, and adopt as pur motto: "All for each, and each
for all."

Industry.

which college
"You'll be buried in the big company," say
some. "Everything is red tape and departments working against each other."
"Your little company never gets you anywhere," others assert. "The bigger the
company the bigger your opportunity."
And that seems true—but in a different
sense. Not physical size but bigness of purpose
should be our standard for judging an industrial organization just as it is for judging a man.
Where will you find this company with
a vision?
Whether its plant .covers a hundred acres
or is only a dingy shop up three flights is on
the face of it no indication of what you want
to know—is such and such a company more
concerned with developing men and ideas than
boosting profits at the expense of service?
You must look deeper. What is the organization's standing in the industry What do
its customers say? What do its competitors say?
There are industries and there are companies
which offer you every opportunity to grow.
Spiritually they are as big and broad as the
earnest man hopes to build himself. If you
are that kind of man you will be satisfied with
a company of no lower standards.
Conversely, if you are working for such a
big-souled company, the very fact will argue
that you yourself are a man worth while. For
in business as in social life a man is known by
the company he picks.
The electrical industry needs men who can
see far and think straight.

to the aspirations of those who work
